poem:
Title: "A Song for Modern Love"

Though Billie sings a feast of love,
Today's muse, not plump on pews 
but tongues, tastes, touches.
Thighs dance in queer rapture,
A dance, unorthodox, unapologetic,
Siren song ripens in raw revelation,
Her voice - lunch for famished hearts,
Amid the dross of common sounds,
crowing a love unsheathed,
Echoes from the vinyl to the fleshy dawn.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘I could eat that girl for lunch’: the sexually explicit queer female pop topping the charts ‘I could eat that girl for lunch / yeah she dances on my tongue, tastes like she might be the one.” So runs the chorus to one of the biggest pop songs of the year, Billie Eilish’s Lunch – the latest star to join a host of others singing about lesbian love, with lyrics full of tongues, touches, thighs". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: ‘I could eat that girl for lunch’: the sexually explicit queer female pop topping the charts ‘I could eat that girl for lunch / yeah she dances on my tongue, tastes like she might be the one.” So runs the chorus to one of the biggest pop songs of the year, Billie Eilish’s Lunch – the latest star to join a host of others singing about lesbian love, with lyrics full of tongues, touches, thighs
